Use the {@creature cult fanatic} in the core rulebooks, as Otto is totally loyal to the Countess and sees that the living serve her needs and will, in exchange for a promise of eternal life; though he does have a means of escaping with his ill-gotten loot, should the Countess not hold up her side of the bargain.

entries.name: Clues and Loot
entries: Hidden in a secret alcove under the floorboards of his house—Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) {@dc 15} to find—are the following items taken from the villagers and travelers that were slain: 300 gp; 2,000 sp; 4 10-gp gems; a {@item finely crafted lute|RolledTold6} (worth 250 gp); assorted silver platters, candlesticks, and cutlery (total value 200 gp); 2 {@item spell scroll||scrolls} with {@spell cure wounds} spells; and 4 {@item potion of animal friendship||potions of animal friendship}. Along with the treasure is a crude but accurate map of a tunnel that leads away from town, starting in the graveyard and ending in the forest, but bypassing the road until five miles away from the village. With the map, the PCs could escape the village and avoid the masses of wolves that roam the forest.

entries.name: 6: The Branded Bear Trading Post
entries: This rough timbered building is chock-full of trade goods, gear, and used weapons and armor. It is run by a very grubby hill dwarf named Grub Anvilclod. Use the {@creature Thug} stat block (see core rulebooks). He does not barter; the price is the price. He is also loyal to the Countess, though more out of greed and self-preservation than true loyalty.

entries.name: Clues and Loot
entries: There is a 50% chance that any basic weapon or armor can be found here in used condition. A Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) {@dc 15} raises the suspicion that most of the gear here has blood stains and/or battle damage, and generally it is as if an attack came from the back or from some form of animal; Intelligence ({@skill Nature}) {@dc 10} show that some marks come from wolf bites, though other bites are unidentifiable. There is a varied collection of used cloaks and clothing, all with the same signs of battle as the armor. Most other equipment from the {@filter equipment|items|type=adventuring gear} section of the core rulebooks is available (used for full price) except for any of the following: {@item holy water (flask)|PHB|holy water}, {@item holy symbol|PHB|holy symbols}, {@item steel mirror|PHB|mirrors}, {@item hunting trap|PHB|hunting traps}, and {@item component pouch|PHB|spell component pouches}.

entries.name: 7: The Old Graveyard
entries: The first thing that is blatantly clear for all to see from within bowshot distance is that every grave in the sizable old boneyard has been dug up and appears empty. A passive {@skill Perception} {@dc 15} reveals a veritable minefield of rudimentary noise traps (pots and pans or bits of metal strung on strings and braided ropes). If the traps are seen, they're easily avoided; if not, the PCs will need a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw or else a cavalcade of noise rings out as a spider web-like collection of tripwires sets every pot and pan a-ringing and a-clanking, alerting everyone within the graveyard. In addition, the entire perimeter of the graveyard is ringed with {@item hunting trap|PHB|hunting traps} (wolf traps) from the equipment section of the core rulebooks. A Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) {@dc 10} shows the ring of traps is set up in a way to best ward off wolves.
What's of note is that in the graveyard near the center is a small, stone mausoleum. A Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) {@dc 20} shows that the doors of the mausoleum as ever so slightly ajar.

Rolf, a massive human warrior (use the {@creature Berserker} from the core rulebooks for stats), and Steiner, a slight, rat-faced fellow (use the {@creature Bandit Captain}) are holed up inside the mausoleum. The two, along with Pickles the halfling, have been waging a losing war trying to rid the village of the vampire and her minions. They are standoffish at first, unless the PCs say Pickle sent them or if any of the PCs have {@item holy symbol|PHB|holy symbols} showing. Rolf and Steiner make all the PCs take a drink from a flask of {@item holy water (flask)|PHB|holy water} to make sure they are not undead. As a GM, you can feel free to make up any number of ludicrous tests the PCs must pass for the duo to trust them. Once they finally establish trust, the duo tells the PCs whatever they want to know. They know everything about the vampire lair except the actual number of {@creature wolf||wolves}, vampires, and {@creature zombie||zombies}. They know a large pack of wolves guards the ruins during the day and that {@creature vampire spawn} join them at night. They also know where the entrance to the true lair in the cellars of the old manor is. As for the villagers, they know only that Elder Otto, the innkeeper, and Grub the dwarf all work for the vampire and suspect all the workers at the inn are the same. Rolf and Steiner also suspect that Grub the hill dwarf sells all the gear looted from the poor souls the vampires drink and then turn into {@creature zombie||zombies}. The duo is more than willing to help in any way they can, so long as it gets them closer to ending the Countess' hold on the town. Rolf and Steiner did not dig up the graves. The Countess used some form of scroll to raise the entire graveyard soon after taking control. Now the old graveyard is the safest place in the area, aside for dealing with the wolves.

entries.name: Gear the Duo has Collected Besides what is listed on their Stat Blocks

items: 4 barrels of smoked and salted wolf meat

entries.name: Other Features and Clues of Note
entries: A ring of half0harvested and limbless trees forms a sort of marked barrier around the village clearing. Beyond them the terrain becomes rugged hills and dense stands of pines. An Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) {@dc 20} of the barrier tree poles finds each has a barely noticeable, but crude {@language Celestial} rune for protection carved into it. An Intelligence ({@skill Arcana} or {@skill Religion}) {@dc 15} shows that the rune was a crude attempt at trying to cast a {@spell hallow} spell around the entire town. With a successful check, it is clear that whoever attempted the massive spell had only rudimentary knowledge of its workings and had no chance of success. An Intelligence ({@skill Nature}) {@dc 10} shows the rune was freshly carved within the past {@dice 1d4} days.

If the PCs meet Rolf and Steiner hiding out at the old cemetery, they find that they were the ones who tried to cast the {@spell hallow} spell to stave off the undead. It's only one of many failed attempts at stopping the vampire and her minions that the duo has made.

Characters with a passive {@skill Perception} of 12+ or who are trained in the {@skill Nature} take note of the following: There is an unnaturally large amount of wolf activity for even a remotely civilized area. Also, the gray, loping forms of wolves are more than a common sight along the roadways and at the edge of the village and even more common on the rugged hill by the ruins of the old manor.

Characters trained in {@skill Nature} or {@skill Survival} skills take note of the following: The coiling fog that seemingly perpetually clings to village and surrounding forest persists no matter the precipitation or wind speed. Most disturbing is how the misty fog sometimes moves against the wind, flowing river-like through the village from the old manor or seeming to take eerie forms, like beckoning claws, withering serpents, or yawning skulls just at the edge of a person's vision. Any character that notices this is allowed an Intelligence ({@skill Religion}) {@dc 20} to identify such fog as being a sign of a vampire's lair.
However the PCs conclude that something, if not everything, is tied to the old manor ruins on the hill, when they decide to investigate, read them the following:

The winding, hard-hewn stone stairs twist up the steep hillock like a serpent fleeing the clinging fog. Where fog does not cover them, the dingy white stones are half-covered with sickly black creepers or are displaced by the tangled roots of stunted and mostly dying pines. The haphazard climb leads to the half-toppled and blackened ruin perched on the knotted hillock. The jagged beams and post of the aged structure are reminiscent of a charred, skeletal hand reaching up from a mounded grave.
The timing of the PCs approaching the manor ruins greatly determines what forces are guarding the toppled structure and the cellar entrance to the vampire's lair.

entries.name: Daylight Hours
entries: 20 {@creature wolf||wolves} (see core rulebooks for stats) and 1 alpha wolf (same as the normal wolf entry, though with maximum (18) hit points) lounge and wander through the ruins and will attack any non-undead that enter the ruins. If the alpha is slain before entry into the cellar lair is made, the Countess will be fully aware of the PCs, as she has a connection with the beast.

entries.name: Any Time After Sunset
entries: If any of the {@creature vampiric minion|RolledTold6|vampiric minions} or {@creature vampire spawn} are slain before the PCs enter the cellar lair, the Countess will be fully aware of the PCs.

items.name: Loot:
items.entry: Amongst the rubble near the cellar entrance are the gnawed and cracked bones of numerous small humanoids and small animals. Along with the bones, Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) {@dc 14} uncovers a {@item ring of protection} (see core rulebooks).

entries.name: 1A: Descent into the Lair

entries: The mingled reek of damp earth, mold, and rotting corpses assaults your senses from the wide, stone stairs that lead down into the waiting darkness. Your skin crawls with the unnatural feeling that seems to pull at you from the unseen, yet inevitable danger the grave-like gloom silently promises.
These stairs lead to {@area 2A|2a}. It is 20 ft. down the stairs to a landing and then another 10 ft. from there down to the floor of the vaulted cellar {@area 2A|2a|x}.

entries.name: 2A: Zombies and the Dirt Nappers

entries: This massive chamber is a mingled mass of oddly placed, stacked stone support pillars, mounds of fresh earth, and piles of snapped and sundered wood that looks to have been racks for wine or shelves for preserved foodstuffs at one time. The source of the reek is a shuffling mob of what looks to be the animated corpses of men, women, and children. The shambling mob fills most of the open spaces of this high-ceilinged room that appear to have three exits, though all are currently closed off with heavy wooden doors.

The ceiling heigh is 30 ft. in this chamber. The walls are dry-set stone, the stairs are solid stone block, and the {@object pillars|RolledTold6} are stacked and mortared stone. All the {@object doors|RolledTold6} are of stout wood, and all but the doors to {@area 3A|3a} are unlocked, but closed. The doors to {@area 3A|3a} are chained from the {@area 2A|2a|x} side and padlocked (lock {@dc 20}), and only the Countess has the key, which is amongst her things in her coffin (see {@area 6A|6a}).

No matter if it is day or night, 30 {@creature zombie||zombies} are wandering about this large chamber. They will not walk up the stairs unless they notice a living creature. They have orders to attack any living creature that comes down the stairs or enters the main chamber.

But they are not the only threats to worry about. There are 6 {@creature vampiric minion|RolledTold6|vampiric minions} (during the day they are buried in piles of dirt on the floor and crawl out {@dice 1d4} rounds after the first {@creature zombie} is engaged in combat; after sundown they hang upside-down, bat-like amongst the rafters—passive {@skill Perception} {@dc 14} to see—and drop down on any foes engaged with the horde of zombies.
The piles of broken wood are each infested with 2 {@creature swarm of centipedes||swarms of centipedes} that will attack anything that disturbs the wood.

entries.name: Loot
entries: One of the {@creature vampiric minion|RolledTold6|vampiric minions} is wearing a {@item gold locket|RolledTold6} worth 10 gp. In the pile of wood by the stairs—Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) {@dc 15} to find—is a heavy leather case that holds two 100-gp value bottles of rare wine that have somehow survived the destruction of the wooden rack.

entries.name: 3A: The Larder

entries: Through the double doors, once the chain is removed, you find what looks to have once been a root cellar. Now three shipping crates made to look like coffins and a pile of dirty blankets stands before you. low, mewing sounds and sniffling come to your ears from behind all of the crates.

The doors that lead to this chamber are chained and locked (see {@area 2A|2a} for details). Beyond is a rectangular chamber that had once been used as a root cellar. Now a large pile of dirty blankets and three shipping crates made into crude coffins are its only furnishings. Cowering behind the crates are six children (taken as a ready food source for the vampires by the inn staff while they and their parents—now zombies in {@area 2A|2a}—were visitors at the inn over the past few weeks). Use the {@creature Commoner}'s stats from core rulebooks for the children, but they are malnourished and scared out of their wits and count as having two levels of exhaustion when found. The only information the children can tell the PCs is that there at one time had been twelve of them, where now there are six.

entries.name: Threats
entries: None

entries.name: Loot
entries: None

entries.name: 4A: The Slab Chamber

entries: Beyond the double doors lie three stone slabs that once were used to keep grain sacks and grains from having to be stacked on the hard-packed dirt floor.

entries.name: If it is day time when the room is explored add in the following
entries: The slabs now serve as sleeping slabs for the trio of vampires laid out, as if ready for burial, upon them.

entries.name: If it is after sundown add the following instead
entries: A trio of hissing vampires with read glaring eyes scuttle crablike off the slabs and rush up the walls!
The three vampires are {@creature vampire spawn} and if awake, will fight to the death.
If it is daylight, the {@creature vampire spawn||vampire spawns} only awaken once the first one is attacked; otherwise they lay in a dormant state until sundown.

entries.name: Loot
entries: The {@creature vampire spawn} have the following items divided between them: a small belt {@item pouch|PHB} containing 20 10-gp {@item lapis lazuli} gems, a {@item small gold bracelet|RolledTold6} worth 25 gp, and a pair of {@item boots of elvenkind} (see core rulebooks).

entries.name: 5A: Chamber of Shackled Souls

entries: Six black iron coffins are laid out int win rows of three along the walls of this low-ceilinged, oblong room. The grim back poxes are draped in thick chains and form an aisle-like gap that leads from the double doors to a yawning arched doorway opposite it.

Here the ceiling is only 10 ft. high. The walls, floor, and ceilings are stone slabs. The double wooden {@object doors|RolledTold6} are unlocked, though with rusty hinges (disadvantage to {@skill Stealth}, if trying to enter the room using the door.

Each of the black iron coffins hold a terrible foe, a {@creature shackled soul|RolledTold6} (use the {@creature specter} as found in the core rulebooks with the following changes. A specter that is a shackled soul suffers no damage from any direct attacks except radiant damage attacks. The only way to defeat them is to destroy the remains they are shackled to. If you do 10 non-magical or 5 fire damage to the remains, the shackled soul is instantly destroyed. Other than radiant attacks, they cannot be harmed.

Getting to the remains of these 6 shackled souls will be difficult. The remains in this instance are sealed within the chained black iron {@object coffin|RolledTold6|coffins}. A shackled soul can only move 20 ft. away from its earthly remains, held to that length by spectral chains. The shackled souls are essentially {@creature specter||specters}, though with the listed modification, making them a hard-to-best foe, if the remains are locked away or protected.

These six {@creature shackled soul|RolledTold6|shackled souls} are the six adventurers that slew Countess Crina's beloved vampiric maker Count Jarek years ago. She hunted each and every one of them down and through foul alchemical sorcery turned them into the wild, life-hating undead specters they now are. They are wholly mad and twisted things that both long for an ending and hate all living things. She keeps them around, because it amuses her that her most hated enemies now guard her sleeping chambers and will try and slay anything living that dares enter within their reach.

items: 6 {@creature specter||specters} (see core rulebooks, {@creature shackled soul|RolledTold6|shackled souls}—see above for details.)

entries.name: Loot
entries: Each of the black iron {@object coffin|RolledTold6|coffins} that holds the remains of an adventurer also holds some of their magical gear, since the Countess had the six poor souls sealed within their iron prisons while still alive.

items.name: Black iron coffin 1
items.entry: {@item +2 Dagger} and 6 50-gp rubies.

items.name: Black iron coffin 2
items.entry: {@item Medallion of thoughts}

items.name: Black iron coffin 3
items.entry: {@item Cloak of protection}

items.name: Black iron coffin 4
items.entry: {@item Bracers of archery}

items.name: Black iron coffin 5
items.entry: {@item Helm of comprehending languages}

items.name: Black iron coffin 6
items.entry: {@item Goggles of night}

entries.name: 6A: The Countess' Crypt

entries: Two leering statues flank the arched entry. Both statues are depictions of a handsome but grim looking warrior, garbed in ornate plate and a voluminous cloak. Something about these statues' features look animalistic or feral. Directly across from the entrance is a raised stone dais with an expertly crafted stone sarcophagus laid atop it. A strange and unnatural fog carpets the crypt, misty tendrils nearly stroking the legs of the twin statues. Almost as if on cue, the sarcophagus slides easily askew and a darkly beautiful woman, dressed in ivory bridal garb sensually rises in a fluid motion not achievable by any natural being.

The time of day when the PCs enter has no bearing, as the Countess is aware they have entered her lair. She will not be rushed and will languidly rise out of her sarcophagus as they enter. She always sleeps cuddled with the skull of her beloved and 2 of the {@creature vampiric minion|RolledTold6|vampiric minions}. The minions will quickly scuttle out of the sarcophagus and up onto the walls and be ready to defend their mistress.

entries.name: Roleplaying: Playing the Countess
entries: Countess Crina is in truth a mad loon. randomly choose one male PC: This character she will not injure because he reminds her of her beloved Count in some small fashion. She will try to subdue that PC and turn them into a {@creature vampire}. Randomly choose one other PC: This PC the Countess will hate and whenever possible focus her attacks on them, as they somehow remind her addled mind of one of those that took her beloved Count from her. The Countess, like most vampires, is a dangerous foe, but her madness will most likely lead to her defeat. To simulate this mad and erratic behavior, each combat round roll {@dice 1d8} for the Countess and use her actions accordingly.

entries.caption: Countess Crina
rows: She howls and thrashes about madly, tears at her own hair, face, and clothing while screaming for her lost beloved Count. (She takes no actions.)

She seeks out the randomly chosen PC that reminds her of her beloved Count and sweetly talks and coos to them like a child, while trying to grab them so she can drink them dry, only to be raised to her service. She will make every attempt, even to her own detriment to grab the chosen PC.

Her seething hatred of the randomly chosen PC makes her go to any length to try and end them, no matter the risk to herself (such as using {@spell fireball} in a space that will hit her as well). She attacks the chosen PC as viciously as possible (note: if randomly chosen PC is killed, randomly choose another, and now something about them reminds the Countess of her hated foe.)
The Countess acts with all her vampiric prowess, seemingly sane and deadly. Use her abilities to her benefit and pick any actions best suited to the current situation.

entries: If the Countess drops to 0 hit points and it is not daytime, she tries an use her Misty Escape ability if possible and blend in with the fog of her lair until she can slip outside and to one of the secret crypts she has hidden around the town, or the forest and the mountains, all within 2 hours' time of her lair. Once there, she heals and hatches even more insane and deadly plans, while she now mourns the loss of so many of her beloved and newly made "children."
If it is daytime and she is forced into her Misty Escape, she has no place for her misty form to escape to and is destroyed.

items: 1 {@creature vampire spellcaster} (as in the core rulebooks) and with the added ability to summon {@creature swarm of insects||insect swarms} as part of her Children of the Night ability.

entries.name: Loot
entries: (On the Countess, to be employed in battle as useful. For stats, see magic items in core rulebooks): {@item Necklace of fireballs}, {@item ring of animal influence}, {@item ring of evasion}, {@item wand of magic missiles}, {@item gold-and-ruby wedding ring|RolledTold6} (worth 250 gp), a {@item platinum-and-ruby choker|RolledTold6} (worth 750 gp), and other various jewelry worth a total of 250 gp.

(In the sarcophagus): 20 pp; a wizard's {@item spellbook|PHB}, bound in tanned human flesh, that contains {@filter every 1st and 2nd level wizard spell|spells|class=wizard|level=1;2} form the core rulebooks; the Count's {@item longsword of wounding} +1.

Having faced all the horrors of the vampires, you are plainly surprised you survived. Though even with the threat of the undead seemingly gone, the village, like the old manor, is a broken thing. There is no telling how deep the evil seeds sown by the Countess go, nor what will rise up from them. The village of Raven's Rest is, in your mind, best left only to the ravens, and is a place you will be more than happy to take your leave of. The bad memories of what foulness you found here will hang with you for years to come.

entries.name: At the Mercy of Her Pack
entries: The entire domain of the Countess is randomly patrolled by large packs of wolves (4 wolves per PC or NPC) and anyone trying to leave the area of the village by way of overland through the forest is attacked a few minutes outside of the settlement. Use the {@creature wolf} stats from the core rulebooks. The pack wolves will at first try to drive any humanoid creature back towards the village, growling and using hit and run tactics. If the humanoids head back to the village, the wolves will shadow them the entire way. If half or more of the wolves are slain, {@dice 1d4} more wolves show up on initiative count 20 each round until the humanoids fall back to the village (see above) or are all slain, whichever comes first.

If such an encounter happens after sundown, and additional wolves are required, then along with the 1d4, roll {@dice 1d20}. A result of 15-19 on the d20 means a {@creature vampiric minion|RolledTold6} comes to aid the wolves. On a result of 20 a {@creature vampire spawn} comes to aid the wolves. If a spawn shows up, the mission becomes to just slay any humanoid the wolves were fighting.

If a character or NPC tries to leave the village via one of the roads, every quarter mile away from the village they are met by a pack of wolves. The wolves at first just growl a warning and slowly push in towards those trying to leave. If the characters or NPCs fall back towards the village, then the wolves shadow them back until they fully return. If the characters or NPCs attack, the wolves fight to the death. Then a quarter mile later another pack is waiting for those trying to leave. This continues until a point of five miles from the village is reached along {@area Road A|a|x}, until a point of two miles away from the village is reached on {@area Road C|c|x}, or until the old woodcutter camp is reached six miles along {@area Road B|b|x}, at which point anyone in the old camp is subject to attack as if they had left via the forest (see above).

If any character or NPC manages to survive to a point two miles into the mountains from the village or five miles from the village in every other direction, then they have truly escaped the Countess' domain.

data.name: Ghosts in the Night
entries: Written by Phil McClorey

entries.name: A 5E Low-Tier Adventure
entries: You will need a copy of the 5E core rulebooks to fully utilize this adventure. You need to familiarize yourself with the adventure and the map to fully enjoy this adventure. It is intended for low-tier characters (level 3).

entries.name: Glossary
entries: PC: Playable Characters. GM: Game Master. DC: Difficulty Class. HP: Hit Points. NPC: Non-Player Character.

entries.name: Plot
entries: The tiefling necromancer, {@creature Nija Necrosis|RolledTold6}, has raised a small force of undead to attack the Shrine of Lover's Sacrifice during when a pair of elven ghosts are set to reappear. As the undead assault the hill and attack the player characters, Nija will attempt a ritual to absorb the ethereal energy of the ghosts into her newly constructed necromantic item, the {@item Staff of Revenant|RolledTold6}, activating its powers. It's up to the player characters to stop Nija's ritual before the spirits of the elves are consumed by her necromantic device.

entries.name: Background
entries: The Shrine of Lover's Sacrifice has stood over a millennium to commemorate the sacrifice of a pair of elven lovers who gave up their lives to prevent an abyssal dimensional rift from opening on the material plane. In honor of their sacrifice a small shrine was constructed as the base of the hill. On the hundredth anniversary of their sacrifice the ghosts of the elven couple appear and re-enact the ritual.

The ghostly couple have since returned each night of their hundredth anniversary. Some believe that the power of their love for each other was so strong that even in death their spirits are still together. Other sages speculate the manifestation of the ghosts is a residual effect of the magic harnessed to seal the abyssal rift. None can say for sure.

The current protector of the shrine, Elora Silverdew, has learned that a powerful necromancer plans to disrupt the appearance of the ghosts and harness their ethereal energies for their own diabolical purpose. She has sought out the adventurers to protect the ghosts during their reappearance.

entries.name: Rules
entries: Either the GM or one of the players can play Elora Silverdew. Use the {@creature priest} stats (see core rulebooks) for this NPC.

The ritual occurs at night. If the players suffer {@condition blinded} conditions (if they do not have {@sense darkvision}), use a torch or stand within the radius of the {@spell continual flame} torches adorning the hilltop.

The {@spell continual flame} torches provide bright light in a 20 foot radius and dim light for an additional 20 feet. Player characters without {@sense darkvision} have disadvantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks in dim light.

The smoke created from the {@item eversmoking bottle} will heavily obscure the area in a 60 foot radius. That radius will increase by 10 feet every minute up to a radius of 120 feet. A moderate wind can disperse the smoke after 1 minute; a strong wind can do so after 1 round.
The {@creature zombie||zombies} used by Nija are her undead thralls. They do an additional +4 to their weapon damage rolls. See {@creature Nija Necrosis|RolledTold6|Nija's NPC stats} for more detail.

A profound feeling of peace washes over you as you stand before the archway of the Shrine of Lover's Sacrifice. Beyond the archway a series of worn stone steps wind up a gently sloping hill. 20 feet from the top of the hill, planted into the ground at each of the compass points, you see a five-foot staff adorned with a glowing stone. Around the staves a number of flower wreaths have been laid to commemorate the sacrifice of the elven lovers who gave their lives to seal a rift to the abyssal planes a millennium ago.

A half-elven priestess adorned in purple robes, her reddish-brown hair falling over a silver circlet, smiles warmly as she greets your arrival. "Thank you for coming. I am Elora Silverdew. It brings me great joy to see you here, answering my call for aid. I fear a great evil will befall the shrine this night. We cannot allow that to happen. The memory, the very spirits of the couple that sacrificed their lives to protect this world must not be allowed to fall to darkness. I will lay down my life if I must to prevent this. I do not ask this of you. However, I do ask for the aid of your swords and spells for as long as you're willing and able to give them."

entries.name: The Shrine of Lovers' Sacrifice
entries: When questioned by the player characters, Elora can provide the information contained in the adventure background.

If a player character asks how she came by the information of the coming attack, Elora answers she received a dream vision from her goddess. In the dream she saw dark arcane magic cast by a black-robed figure absorbing the ethereal energy of the ghosts. The only feature she observed of the magic user was a purple tail swinging freely from underneath their black robes.

The shrine archway stands at the base of the hill. From it, a winding stone pathway leads to the summit one hundred feet up the hill. surrounding the top of the hill are four wooden polls adorned with {@spell continual flame} spells. each pole sits on a compass point twenty feet from the summit. The base of the hill is surrounded by oak and maple trees so that anything moving in the area is lightly obscured and creatures have disadvantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

entries.name: The Assault on the Shrine
entries: Allow the players the opportunity to determine how they want to defend the hill. Elora will insist that she be near the top of the hill, where the ghosts will appear.

Night has fallen. A crescent moon hangs in the sky amidst a myriad of stars. The flame from the torches bathes the hilltop. A gentle breeze rises, stirring the flower wreaths as ethereal lights begin to twinkle on the summit.

"Look! It has begun," Elora calls out, pointing to the clearing. Slowly the lights take shape. A pair of elves takes form, a male wood elf, his hair bound with feathers, dressed in leather armor fashioned like a coat of leaves and a female high elf, her long braided hair brushing the hem of her arcana robes. The ghosts embrace and being a haunting, magical dance, re-enacting their last moments together.
A low horn peels from the surrounding woods. Elora glances towards you. "They are coming. Stand fast!"
A wall of smoke rolls out form the eastern edge of the wood, flowing up the hillside and obscuring your vision of the forest.

{@creature Gorbundus Kimbatuul|RolledTold6|Gorbundus}, the dragonborn knight, has unstoppered his {@item eversmoking bottle} 10 feet inside the forest on the eastern slope of the hill. The smoke has a radius of 60 feet and covers the first 50 feet of the hillside, heavily obscuring the area.

entries.name: Threat
items: 4 {@creature zombie||zombies}, 33 hp and 8 ({@damage 1d6+5}) bludgeoning damage due to Nija's Undead Thrall ability.

entries: The {@creature zombie||zombies} and {@creature Gorbundus Kimbatuul|RolledTold6} will use the smoke to cover their approach, although the player characters may smell the rotting corpses. The {@creature zombie||zombies} will take ta double movement on their turn, heading towards the top of the hillside to attack the nearest player characters. Following behind them will be {@creature Gorbundus Kimbatuul|RolledTold6|Gorbundus}. Gorbundus will allow the zombies to engage the player characters first before making his attack. If he uses his breath weapon during the battle he will try and catch more than one player in the 15-foot radius cone.
The second attack comes from the western slope of the hill by a pair of shadows.

The shadows will attempt to use their Shadow Stealth ability to surprise and attack a player character that is focused on the approaching zombies. They will try to stay out of the bright light created from the {@spell continual flame} torches unless they have no other options when engaging a player character.
The last attack comes from the north side of the hill, from {@creature Nija Necrosis|RolledTold6} and her {@creature ogre zombie} carrying the {@item Staff of Revenant|RolledTold6}.

entries.name: Threat
items: {@creature Ogre zombie}, 96 HP and 16 ({@damage 2d8+8}) bludgeoning damage due to Nija's Undead Thrall ability.

entries: The pair is {@condition invisible} until they make an action. The Ogre zombie will plant the {@item Staff of Revenant} in the ground 10 feet from the top of the hill. After that it will stay within 10 feet of Nija acting as her bodyguard. The ogre zombie will not chase the player characters. Once the staff is in place Nija will use an action to activate it. It will take 1 minute for the staff to absorb the energy of the ghosts. On her next turn Nija will cast {@spell globe of invulnerability}. She will the use her spells to engage the players from a distance keeping one second and fourth level spell slot available to cast {@spell dimension door} and {@spell invisibility} if she needs to escape. Nija will attempt to flee once she has lost more than half her hit points.

Players can attempt to deactivate the staff by casting {@spell dispel magic} and making an ability check at {@dc 17} using their spellcasting ability. Nija can reactivate the staff using an action. Player characters can also attack the staff, attempting to deactivate it by destroying it. The {@object Staff of Revenant|RolledTold6} has an AC of 20 and 35 hp. If the staff is destroyed it explodes. Every creature in a 15-foot radius of the staff must make a Constitution saving throw {@dc 15} or take 16 ({@damage 3d10}) necrotic damage, half on a successful save.

On the second turn of combat, initiative count 1, the elven ghosts will cast {@spell bless} on three of the player characters who are within thirty feet. On the fifth round of combat they will cast {@spell mass cure wounds} healing as many player characters within range as they can for 16 ({@dice 3d8+3}) hit points.

data.name: Ending the Adventure

entries.name: If the players are successful in repelling Nija's assault read the following below
entries: The battle is won; the forces assaulting the Shrine of Lover's Sacrifice have been defeated! Soon after, the ritual reaches its climax. The pair of ethereal elves spiral towards the sky, the light of their love shining like a beacon. Their light washes over you, suffusing you with its magical radiance. It grows in intensity, blazing like the sun for a brief moment before winking out of existence.
The ghosts are gone.

With their parting, the ghosts have gifted the players with a minor supernatural gift, a {@reward charm of heroism}, which acts like a {@item potion of heroism}. It can be used only once. If Elora is still alive she will be exhausted and overjoyed that they have succeeded.

entries.name: If Nija was successful in capturing the elven ghosts read the following to the players
entries: The ghosts are torn from their embrace as their ethereal energy is sucked into the demonic skull adorning the staff planted in the ground. "The power of their love to overcome death is now mine," the necromancer cackles, "and through my {@item Staff of Revenant|RolledTold6} the mysteries of the realm of the dead will soon be fully revealed to me!"
And with that final boast, the necromancer casts a spell and vanishes into the night.

A successful Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check {@dc 15} reveals the spell cast to be {@spell dimension door}. Elora, if she still lives, will be distraught at the loss of the ghosts. She will implore the player characters to track down Nija and destroy the staff before more damage can be done by it. But that's an adventure for another day!

data.name: The Demon of Queen's Haven
entries: Written by Adam Ha

entries.name: A 5E Low-Tier Adventure Level-3 Adventure
entries: You will need a copy of the 5E core rulebooks to fully utilize this adventure. You need to familiarize yourself with the adventure and the map to fully enjoy the adventure.

entries.name: Glossary
entries: PC: Playable Characters. GM: Game Master. DC: Difficulty Class. HP: Hit Points. NPC: Non-Player Character.

entries.name: Adventure Scaling
entries: This adventure works best with a party of characters level 5, but could be modified to be more difficult for party of level 5 characters by increasing all enemies (or enthralled townsfolk) to their maximum hit points, and adding an additional cultist {@creature spy} to each encounter.

entries.name: Plot
entries: A famous bardic troupe has come to perform at a local village theater. As attendees gather to see the show, a retired paladin tries to warn those who will listen that not all seems right here. There's a demonic presence somewhere nearby. While she cannot say exactly where it's coming from, she's absolutely certain that someone involved with the musical performance must be responsible...

entries.name: Background
entries: Queen's Haven isn't a true village by most rural standards. Most of its homes are owned by nobility. Inhabited irregularly, there are few farms and even fewer farmers. Heavy investments from foreign aristocrats ensure the village is well stocked, guarded, and maintained. As a seasonal playground for the rich, there are few places more comfortable than Queen's Haven—if you can afford to live there.

So naturally, when it was announced that the Jousting Notes would be performing an exclusive concert for the people of Queen's Haven, gossip spread like wildfire. Wealthy nobles scrambled to purchase seats for what was likely to be one of the most exclusive shows of the year.

It is an understatement to say the Jousting Notes are one of the most popular musical groups across the kingdom. Their performances have been described as a perfect showcase of natural talent and well-practiced showmanship. Notoriously harsh entertainment critic Jean Froun even provided them with a prestigious set of silver bells—an honor only given to musicians of the highest caliber.

All of Queen's Haven is brimming with anticipation for tonight's event, which is why anyone looking to stir up trouble is being treated with extra care. Unfortunately for the demon hunting Sofia Espada, it means being exiled outside of town for causing a stir.

entries.name: Rules
entries: This adventure takes place over a single evening, as PCs explore the village of Queen's Haven in search for evidence of a demon lurking in their midst. Once players feel they have enough evidence against a particular NPC they can accuse that NPC publicly for their crimes.

To help narrow down the list of suspects, players can hunt for clues that will reveal the demon's identity. These clues are scattered throughout Queen's Haven, and range from gossip to corrupted writings (see {@adventure Queen's Haven|1|Queen's Haven} for specific details).

A wrong guess will end their investigation and potentially get them removed from town, while revealing the identity of the demon will force it to lash out against its accusers. Worse yet, players must uncover the culprit before the concert ends, or else the ritual will complete, putting the entire village at risk.

Queen's Haven has always been an active community, but the village has certainly never been this busy in the past. A caravan of expensive and ornate looking carriages, stagecoaches, and wagons have been parked all along the main road leading to the village square. Some even have personal guards standing nearby—expensive-looking hired swords who give cold looks to anyone that gets too close.

It's a lot of fanfare, but you know the reason why. Love 'em or hate 'em, the Jousting Notes are one of the biggest names in bardic performances is in town. Their concert has been highway gossip for weeks. If seats aren't already sold out, they will be soon.

As your group makes their way into town you hear a sharp, distracting whistle. Standing off-road under the shade of a nearby tree is an older human woman, her body wrapped in an old grey cloak. She extends a hand in warm greeting, and you notice the gleam of silver armor hidden away under the folds of her cloth.

"Travelers, please, I mean no harm. Something is amiss in the village ahead, and the captain of their guard will not heed my warnings. I know the word of stranger may not have much weight, but if you can spare but a moment I believe we can save many lives this evening."

She draws a small pendant from a pouch at her side—a silver star hanging in a vial filled with a cloudy liquid. You realize that the grey cloak hides more than her armor. This woman is missing her other arm.

"My name is Sofia. As I was once a knight within the Order of White Ash I can tell you with great certainty that there is a demon among us. I don't know what it intends to do here. I don't care. All that matters is that it must be stopped, and I cannot do so on my own."

Sofia is convinced there's a demon lurking within Queen's Haven, and her suspicions rest heavily on the Jousting Notes being responsible. Since their arrival, she's felt like something is clouding her ability to focus on or sense demons and undead. Worse, when she tried to investigate in preparation for tonight's concert, the troupe's manager had her removed from the village for "disturbing the peace."

Now barred from entering Queen's Haven, Sofia needs help investigating the source of the unholy disturbance. The captain of the guard, Captain Mersen, is an honest man, but he won't make a move against anyone without a good amount of evidence.

Before PCs enter the town they're likely going to have a few questions. Encourage players when making their own knowledge checks to see what information they can gather before going forth. Additionally, Sofia is more than happy to provide information on any details regarding the town, demons, the Order of White Ash, or any other subject that will get players to aid her cause.

You may want to start with an Intelligence ({@skill History}) {@dc 12} on the history of the Jousting Notes. A successful check will reveals some facts about the troupe. Their rise to fame is well noted as a result of their incredible passion for music. They tour many places, from quaint towns to sprawling cities, and don't seem to play favorites when it comes to their performances. Their manager seems to be a recent acquisition, but it's not unusual for performers to be represented in some way. The original band members are as followed:

An Intelligence ({@skill History}) DC 13 on the history of The Order of White Ash (sometimes referred to as the "White Ash") reveals the significance of Sofia's position within the order. They are paladins, banded together to snuff out corruption wherever it may seek a home. More than just men and women with divine talents, the White Ash are also talented trackers. Many dedicate themselves to years of study that result in keen forensic skills, making them incredibly skilled at picking up fine details lesser hunters may miss. The {@item silver star|RolledTold12} is one of many tools iconic to this order, and ownership of such an artifact helps validate her claim of being a member.

entries.name: Before Exploring Queen's Haven
entries: As PCs get ready to hunt for evidence of demonic corruption, Sofia will provide them with some advice and aid:

"Captain Mersen is a good man, but this community is guided more by coin than by morals. He won't be able to take any action unless you've gathered enough evidence against the demon. This should help."
Sofia holds out the vial containing the silver star, nodding for you to take it.

"My own senses are dulled, but this should aid you. The star shines brighter the closer it's brought to unholy idols. It is no judge of character, but an excellent tool when looking to identify the profane."

"Whatever the danger, I fear the demon may be using this concert to mask its intention. You should start by visiting the local inn, Daylight's Rest. The troupe would have taken rooms therefor the evening. If there is something amiss to be found, it may be hidden among their belongings."

entries.name: Queen's Haven
entries: Used mostly as a getaway for the rich, Queen's Haven is unusually clean and well-maintained for a village of its size. Part of this is due to its larger-than-normal town guard, who serves to enforce the peace and protect their wealthy residents from the potential threat of theft.
With so many gathered in town to see the concert, it's very unlikely that PCs will attract much attention from the villagers. Still, town guards are on the look out for thieves and vandals.
When PCs perform an action that may draw attention, be sure to use Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks with both guard and cultist NPCs, as some areas are carefully watched by one or the other.

entries.name: Village Gossip
entries: Queen's Haven is a hub of gossip! The concert has already begun, but PCs can use all kinds of checks to gather information from the locals. No one is being particularly secretive, so let PCs be creative on how they gather intel. A check of any kind above a {@dc 10} will give one or more clues:

items: "I couldn't get a room in town. I think the inn was completely bought out by the Notes! Somethin' about needing privacy."
"My son couldn't get a ticket, so he and his friends tried sneaking in through the cellar. Group of men standin' around back there wouldn't let 'em past."

entries.name: Daylight's Rest
entries: As the only lodgings available in Queen's Haven, Daylight's Rest is usually busy no matter the time of day. Mornings and afternoons are generally filled with hungry travelers looking to fill their bellies, while those looking for a calmer drinking atmo-sphere settle into the bar in the evenings.

Daylight's Rest consists of two main floors and a basement used exclusively for storage. The first floor consists of a bar, spacious dining area for patrons, and kitchen. On the second floor players can find a dozen available rooms for guests, most of which have already been taken by the Jousting Notes.

The main floor is occupied by five patrons, all of whom are demonic cultists in disguise. The barkeep is also in disguise, due to having murdered the actual innkeeper and hiding the body in the kitchen around the corner. The barkeep currently holds the master key.

items: A Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) {@dc 15} will notice a streak of blood on the bar that wasn't cleaned up from the innkeeper's murder.
The moment PCs try to go upstairs to investigate the room, the cultists will arrange for an ambush. They will wait out of sight until the time is right to strike and kill PC intruders.
Use the {@creature cultist} and {@creature cult fanatic} profiles from the core rulebooks to represent the 5 patrons and barkeep respectively.

items.name: Threats:
items.entry: 5 {@creature cultists} (patrons) 1 {@creature cult fanatic||cultist priest}

items.name: Loot:
items.entry: 15 gp, plus weapons and armor.

entries: Rooms are locked on the second floor but can be broken into with a Dexterity ({@item thieves' tools|PHB}) {@dc 15}, or the master key. None of the rooms are labeled, but there are some clues as to which band member has taken which room. Roll a {@dice d6} to determine which of the following rooms players enter if they choose to break in. A PC holding the {@item silver star|RolledTold12} has advantage on their actions when searching a room for demonic corruption. An Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) {@dc 15} in any of the rooms will find the following:

entries.name: 1 - Bill Horton's Room

entries: A single desk has been overtaken by a pile of paperwork, quills, and hanging lanterns, but otherwise this room seems largely unused. The silver star glows faintly in this room.

An Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) {@dc 14} check will reveal the following: tucked away under a pile of ledgers is an old leather tome. Scratchings across the surface seem to be written in dried blood. It is most certainly a language, but it's unclear which one it is.

If a PC can read {@language Abyssal}: Scrawled across the cover is the title {@i Servant's Duties}. Each page goes through tremendous detail on how a lesser being can summon and empower the demonic entity known as {@creature Diafol, the Enthraller|RolledTold12}, who trades human souls in exchange for untold power.

It is Bill who summoned Diafol, trading the life of a trusted band member in exchange for power. The more energy he feeds it, the more powerful he'll become, and he can often be seen close by Darlene/DiafoI.

entries.name: 2 - Darlene Grove's Room

entries: This room is very clean, but rather sparse. An open closet reveals several dresses of varying color and design. The silver star glows faintly in this room

An Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) {@dc 13} will uncover a hidden detail in the room: under the mattress you find something unusual. There lay several small {@object emerald pendant|RolledTold12|emerald necklace pendants}, cut into various shapes. Each emerald is incredibly detailed, and though it may seem like a trick of the light, you could swear the gem may have even moved.

Donning an {@object emerald pendant|RolledTold12} will immediately submit the wearer to a {@dc 16} Wisdom saving throw. Failure will submit the wearer to the commands of the {@item emerald keystone|RolledTold12} (Bill Horton) as per the emerald keystone's effects (see under {@adventure New Magic Items|DemonQueensHaven|3}).

entries.name: 3 - Leon King's Room

entries: The room seems incredibly well organized. Expensive looking instrument cases have been organized around the room on tables, chairs, and in some cases, standing neatly on the ground.
PCs can find a guitar, {@item flute|PHB}, violin, fiddle, recorder, {@item drum|PHB}, tambourine, and miniature harp. Each item has a case inscribed with the letters L.K., even the tambourine.

entries.name: 4 - Lysindra Goldring's Room

entries: The room is in a bit of disarray. Flamboyantly colored dresses have been left strewn on the floor, the bed is unmade, and it looks like whomever is staying here must be a fairly messy individual.

An Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) {@dc 16} will uncover the diary of Lysindra Goldring. It contains a few details about their travel around the country, but nothing that would suggest anything demon-related.

The room contains only a single stand for holding a guitar case. Around the room are several portraits, some sketched and some painted, of a shirtless orcish male in various thrilling poses with a golden guitar.
A completely unremarkable bedroom in this comfortable-looking inn. It doesn't appear like anyone is staying here.

entries.name: Eventide Strip
entries: The Eventide Strip is more of a theater than it is a bar or pub. Patrons can see nightly shows, generally while being comfortably seated and with an expensive drink in hand. While performances occur nightly, this evening's special occasion is focused entirely on the Jousting Notes.

A pair of town guards are checking tickets at the door, while four others are indoors to ensure the peace is kept. There are easily over twenty patrons packed into the dining hall—a collection of wealthy individuals who sit huddled together in cliques and social groupings. Stairs lead up to a balcony that offers a bit more seated space, and a view down to the main stage from above. The {@item silver star|RolledTold12} glows faintly in this room.

entries.name: 1 - The Main Stage
entries: The Jousting Notes are performing on stage, and the audience seems completely absorbed with the performance, both the patrons and guards alike. There are approximately twenty nobles and four guards present in the room. Once players enter the main floor they'll need to pass a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw or they'll become enthralled in Darlene Grove's performance, as though under the effects of the spell {@spell hypnotic pattern}.
Resisting the effect gives players an idea that something is amiss. Failure means the PC will become compelled to watch the performance, with a specific focus on Darlene.

items: Enthralling pendants: All band members except for Darlene are visibly wearing small {@object emerald pendant|RolledTold12|emerald pendants}, enchanted to compel the members to continue playing music no matter what occurs. If players uncovered the {@object emerald pendant|RolledTold12|emerald pendants} in Darlene Grove's room, they could notice this detail with a {@dc 13} passive Perception

These pendants have 2 hp, and can be automatically hit so long as they're not being worn. If worn, their small size gives them an 13 AC when attacked in a way that won't harm the wearer. Otherwise, use the AC of whoever is wearing it (use the {@creature commoner} profile for any of the performers).

entries: Manager Bill Horton (use the {@creature cult fanatic} stat block in the core rulebooks) is in the audience and will assist Darlene/Diafol if they are attacked. He currently holds the {@item emerald keystone|RolledTold12} and is directing the remainder of the musical troupe to perform in tandem with Darlene/Diafol.

entries.name: 2 - Cellar
entries: Behind the entrance to the Eventide is a large cellar, intended for storing food and furniture used in the performance hall above. Four men in cloaks stand guard over the cellar entrance. Even at a distance they appear on edge, reaching for their blades as they peer around them.

The guards here are all previously indoctrinated members of the demon's cult in disguise, who infiltrated Queen's Haven in advance (use the {@creature spy} statblock in the core rulebooks). Though currently guarding the cellar, they are ready to kill anyone who gets too close without reservation. The cellar door is unlocked, and torchlight accompanied by voices in the basement below suggest there are other cultists nearby.

items.name: Threats:
items.entry: 4 cultist {@creature spy||spies}

items.name: Loot:
items.entry: 5 gp, plus weapons and armor.

entries.name: 3 - Eventide Basement
entries: The angle of the cellar stairs and height of the basement's ceiling make it difficult to see inside without going further within. Below, players will encounter the remaining cultists—dark acolytes alongside members of Queen's Haven that have been drawn to the demon's influence.

As you descend into the basement, the sounds of low chanting slowly draw to a close. Men and women draped in black robes stand at ready, their colorful evening attire poking out underneath the dark fabric. Flickering candles illuminate a symbol that hangs in between them—bundled sticks and dried grass that have been pulled into an unusual, but intentional, shape: a curved hook.
The {@item silver star|RolledTold12} glows faintly in this room.

Robed figures (use the {@creature cultist} statblock) guard the demonic ward below. As long as the ward is active, any spells with 500 feet that allow the detection of evil or demons will automatically fail. Other tracking abilities (such as a paladin's {@classFeature Divine Sense|Paladin||1}) will fail to detect any demonic presence, even if a demon is physically present.

items.name: Threats:
items.entry: 5 {@creature cultist||cultists}

items.name: Loot:
items.entry: 60 gp split across various expensive-looking coin pouches, plus weapons and armor.

entries.name: Jotred's Forge
entries: The town's smithy is run by the reliable dwarven smith Jotred Yern. Jotred keeps his nose clean of local gossip and isn't a fan of politics. He does enjoy reliable coin, and his forge is open to repair or sell basic goods.

entries.name: Carnelian Bloom
entries: Rich patrons sometimes require exotic cures, and this apothecary is happy to provide. It is run by Teeg Drims (gnome male). In addition to selling basic reagents there's a chance some rarer potions may be in stock:

items: 1d4 {@item potion of water breathing||potions of water breathing}

entries.name: Town Hall / Guardhouse
entries: Queen's Haven uses its town hall as both a place to host important announcements, and a place for its wealthy inhabitants to post work orders for mercenaries or adventurers—anything from guard duty to clearing out a nest of unwanted vermin.

Because most of the guards are on duty within the Eventide Strip (or guarding other local estates), PCs will find the town hall to be rather empty, save for a couple of guards who are happy to provide directions should the need arise. Captain Mersen himself is on guard at the Eventide.

entries.name: Outlying Village Homes
entries: There are several expensive estates scattered throughout Queen's Haven, all of which are private, and beyond the immediate core of the village. Though not a part of the main adventure, PCs may want to go visit one of the multi-floor private mansions for a variety of reasons. Just remember that these homes are large, expensive, and likely very well guarded.

entries.name: Weakening Diafol's Influence
entries: Players must confront the demon before the performance has concluded, but having more evidence will give them clues as how best to disrupt its plan and reveal its true nature.

items: While none of Diafol's cultists will give up the demon willingly, with enough excessive force Diafol's followers could be persuaded to betrayal. Bill Horton was careful to not reveal Diafol's secret identity to any of his followers.

Bill Horton is loyal to Diafol to the death. If Bill has not been revealed to be part of the demonic plot, he will defend Diafol should the demon be discovered (use the {@creature cult fanatic} statblock from the core rulebooks to represent his abilities).

A crude but powerful magic device. When destroyed, the ward will release a 10 ft.-radius burst of psychic energy. Any living creature within the area must succeed at a Wisdom saving throw {@dc 15}, or suffer 3 ({@damage 1d6}) psychic damage. With the demonic ward destroyed, Diafol's true identity can be detected with magical means.
The {@item emerald keystone|RolledTold12|keystone} must first be taken from its owner, Bill Horton.
Destroying the emerald partially breaks the enchantment and prevents new commands from being delivered to those under the effect of an {@object emerald pendant|RolledTold12}.
The {@item emerald keystone|RolledTold12} has 8 hp and a 10 AC.
Just removing a pendant isn't enough to break the enchantment. Commands made from the keystone's holder will stay locked in place for 24 hours after removal.
The moment the {@item emerald keystone|RolledTold12} is destroyed, the effects of the {@object emerald pendant|RolledTold12} dissipate.

entries.name: Confronting Diafol
entries: If players don't find a means of uncovering Diafol's identity, or if they fail to force the demon to show itself, the demon will be content to stay hidden. Otherwise, if revealed, Diafol will attack.

Though disguised as an elven bard, Diafol's true appearance is far more sinister. Darlene's soul was burned out long ago and her body is now only a vessel for the demon's power. As Darlene's body is attacked, more of the false form will burn away to reveal a twisted parody of mortal form underneath—a diseased wretch of a man. Rotten skin rips and peels away from its emaciated form, causing a fetid black substance to leak from its wounds. Despite its appearance, Diafol has incredible strength.

If revealed it will immediately fight, wanting to preserve the control it has over its enthralled audience. Unfortunately, without its guiding voice, the enchanted audience will begin to slip from Diafol's grasp. As {@creature Diafol, scion of enthrallment|RolledTold12|Diafol} combats the party (see NPC statblocks), roll an initiative position for the audience with an unmodified {@dice d20}. Then roll 1d10 at the start of each round:

entries.caption: Audience Actions
rows: The audience uses all its movement to frantically {@action dash} in a random direction. To determine the direction, roll a {@dice d4} and assign a cardinal direction to each die face.
The audience doesn't move or take actions this turn, continuing to enjoy the "show" as though nothing was wrong.

The audience uses its action to fight amongst each other in a sudden burst of violence. Most will be busy trying to attack each other, but some may wildly swing at nearby PCs. Roll {@dice 1d12} to determine how many potential audience members decide to attack PCs. Use the {@creature noble} profile from the core rulebooks to represent the audience. If any guards are present, use the {@creature Queen's Haven guard|RolledTold12} under the {@adventure NPC statblock section|DemonQueensHaven|3}. Guards attack PCs at the GM's discretion.
The audience can act and move normally, suddenly becoming aware of their dilemma, though they are not freed from the enchantment and cannot attack Diafol.

entries.name: If PCs Have Defeated Diafol
entries: With the final blow struck, Diafol's physical form begins to burn away. Sulfur fills the air as the decrepit humanoid form crumbles to black ash. Members of the audience begin to come to their senses as the demonic influence releases its grip. The surviving members of the Jousting Notes bring their performance to a sudden halt. It's not until a clear explanation is provided that the nobles in attendance begin to understand how close they came to mortal peril. They immediately demand more precautions be taken to prevent this sort of incident from happening again.

Sofia Espada, retired Knight of the White Ash, is happy to oblige. Before taking on her new role of Chief Inquisitor she arranges compensation for the brave heroes who believed her during a time of crisis: 1,000 gold, her silver star, and a letter of commendation from the wise and well-traveled knight.

entries.name: If Diafol Escapes, or is Undiscovered
entries: Without knowing where the demon has escaped to, it's difficult to say what its goals were, let alone what kind of damage it caused. Perhaps it learned a lesson in underestimating mortals, and will keep afar distance from Queen's Haven.

Then again, there's no real way to tell if this wasn't just another part of its plan. Either way, Sofia is thankful for the aid in her investigation. She'll stay a while longer in town to help mend the wounded, though it's likely the nobles will ask she be removed again. This time for failing to properly identify the demonic threat. Unable to provide any coin for the trouble, she offers the silver star as a token of her gratitude.
